linkedin_essay.text:
The numbers today are of a scale that would have given Philip II's Genoese bankers a collective seizure.

Global government debt exceeded $100 trillion in 2024, according to the International Monetary Fund â€” roughly 93% of global GDP (IMF, 2024). This figure has nearly tripled since 2007, when it stood at $36 trillion. In the space of seventeen years, the governments of the world have borrowed more than they had accumulated in the entirety of recorded history prior to 2007.

The United States leads the pack in absolute terms, with a national debt of approximately $36.2 trillion in early 2026, representing roughly 124% of GDP (US Treasury, 2026). This is higher, as a proportion of GDP, than at any point since World War II, and it is growing at approximately $1.8 trillion per year â€” roughly $5 billion per day, or $57,000 per second. The Congressional Budget Office projects that, under current law, debt will reach 166% of GDP by 2054 (CBO, 2024). Under less optimistic assumptions â€” a recession, another war, another pandemic, or simply the continuation of current political incentives â€” it could reach 200% within two decades.
